data.title: How much do you know about FASD?
data.description: Click next to begin the quiz.

q.text: How many newborn babies are affected by FASD?
q.response: Nearly 1 out of every 100 babies born is affected by alcohol.

q.text: True or false: Drinking during pregnancy is the only thing that can cause FASD.
q.response: Drinking alcohol during pregnancy is the only cause of FASD. Avoiding alcohol during pregnancy is the only way to prevent it.

q.text: Which of the following problems are associated with FASD?
q.a: Distinctive facial features (for example, wide-set eyes)
Poor judgment (for example, trouble understanding cause and effect)
Cognitive problems (for example, taking longer than usual to understand something)
Sensory processing difficulties (for example, having trouble figuring out where a sound is coming from)
q.response: All of the above are problems that are associated with FASD.

q.text: Which of the following is an example of binge drinking?
q.a: A man having 5 or more drinks in a row
A woman having 4 or more drinks in a row
q.response: All of the above are examples of binge drinking.

q.text: True or false: Women in high school and college are not at high risk for having babies with FASD.
q.response: Women in high school and college are at a high risk for having babies with FASD because they have relatively high rates of binge drinking and unplanned pregnancies.

q.text: Which of the following drinks has the most alcohol?
q.a: A shot of rum, vodka or tequila
A 12 oz can of regular beer
They all have the same amount
q.response: They all have the same amount of alcohol.

q.text: True or false: FASD is very rare.
q.response: FASD is common; in fact, it is the leading cause of developmental disabilities in Canada.

q.text: True or false: One or two drinks per week during pregnancy can’t harm the baby.
q.response: There is no safe amount of alcohol a woman can drink during pregnancy.
